revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=April 2017}} {{use American English|date=March 2017}} {{Infobox comedian | image = Mike_Birbiglia.jpg | name = Mike Birbiglia | imagesize = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1978|6|20}}<ref name=allmusic>{{cite web|url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=mike-birbiglia-mn0000404529/biography|pure_url=yes}} |author=Jeffries, David |publisher=[[Rovi Corporation]]|title=Mike Birbiglia: Biography|work=[[allmusic]]|accessdate=July 23, 2015}}</ref> | birth_place = [[Shrewsbury, Massachusetts]], [[United States]]<ref name=allmusic /> | medium = [[Stand-up comedy|Stand-up]], [[theatre]], [[radio]], [[television]], [[film]] | nationality = [[United States|American]] | spouse = Jen Stein (m. 2007) | children = 1 | active = 2004-present | website = {{url|http://www.birbigs.com}} }}
'''Mike Birbiglia''' (born June 20, 1978) is an American comedian, actor, and filmmaker. He is a frequent contributor to ''[[This American Life]]'' and ''[[The Moth]]'', and has released several comedy albums and television specials. His feature-length directorial debut ''[[Sleepwalk with Me]]'' (2012), based on his one-man show of the same name and in which he also starred, won awards at the [[Sundance Film Festival|Sundance]] and [[Nantucket Film Festival|Nantucket]] film festivals. He also wrote, directed, and starred in the comedy-drama ''[[Don't Think Twice]]'' (2016). His 2010 book ''Sleepwalk with Me and Other Painfully True Stories'' was a [[The New York Times Best Seller list|''New York Times'' bestseller]] and a finalist for the 2011 [[Thurber Prize for American Humor]]. Birbiglia has appeared in films such as ''[[Your Sister's Sister]]'' (2011), ''[[Cedar Rapids (film)|Cedar Rapids]]'' (2011), and ''[[Trainwreck (film)|Trainwreck]]'' (2015), played a recurring role in ''[[Orange Is the New Black]]'', and has guest starred in episodes of ''[[Girls (TV series)|Girls]]'', ''[[Inside Amy Schumer]]'', and ''[[Broad City]]''.
==Early life== Birbiglia was born in [[Shrewsbury, Massachusetts]], the son of Mary Jean (née McKenzie) and Vincent Paul Birbiglia. He is the youngest of four children.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://familytreemaker.genealogy.com/users/p/a/t/Edward-J-Patton-NY/WEBSITE-0001/UHP-0733.html|title=Edward-J-Patton-NY - User Trees|publisher=Genealogy.com|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140821161421/http://familytreemaker.genealogy.com/users/p/a/t/Edward-J-Patton-NY/WEBSITE-0001/UHP-0733.html|archivedate=August 21, 2014|df=mdy-all}}</ref> He is of part Italian descent.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.stltoday.com/entertainment/movies/reviews/comedian-birbiglia-invites-us-to-sleepwalk/article_8ccc2dd8-fc7f-11e1-8e1c-0019bb30f31a.html|title=Comedian Birbiglia invites us to sleepwalk|author=Lee Enterprises|work=stltoday.com|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120915012640/http://www.stltoday.com/entertainment/movies/reviews/comedian-birbiglia-invites-us-to-sleepwalk/article_8ccc2dd8-fc7f-11e1-8e1c-0019bb30f31a.html|archivedate=September 15, 2012|df=mdy-all}}</ref> Birbiglia attended [[St. John's High School (Massachusetts)|St. John's High School, Shrewsbury, Massachusetts]] for one year, and graduated from [[St. Mark's School (Massachusetts)|St. Mark's School, Southborough, Massachusetts]] in 1996.<ref>[[Lisa Birnbach|Birnbach, Lisa]]; [[Chip Kidd|Kidd, Chip]], [https://books.google.com/books?id=pVxlaG0AysIC&printsec=frontcover ''True Prep: It's a Whole New Old World''], Random House Digital, Inc., 2010. Cf. [https://books.google.com/books?id=pVxlaG0AysIC&pg=PA68&lpg=PA68&dq=Mike+Birbiglia+st.+mark%27s+school&source=bl&ots=x9UiuIY0X7&sig=Srd8HhJvpgncXZDANefZ1_Z989E&hl=en&ei=-Rw2TuGIDYHcgQfs7uXOBw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=10&ved=0CGIQ6AEwCQ#v=onepage&q=Mike%20Birbiglia%20st.%20mark%27s%20school&f=false p.68]</ref><ref>[http://www.stmarksschool.org/calendars/detail.aspx?pageaction=VSIPublicBlock2&LinkID=22830&ModuleID=232:260:302&StartDate=5/5/2011 "Mike Birbiglia '96 Comedy Show"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110930203649/http://www.stmarksschool.org/calendars/detail.aspx?pageaction=VSIPublicBlock2&LinkID=22830&ModuleID=232%3A260%3A302&StartDate=5%2F5%2F2011 |date=September 30, 2011 }}, ''St. Mark's School website, Thursday, May 5, 2011</ref> He says seeing comedian [[Steven Wright]] perform inspired him to begin writing jokes at age 16.<ref name="WAPO-Bacic">{{cite news|last1=Bacic|first1=Ryan|title=Mike Birbiglia started in improv. Everything since has gone according to plan.|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/lifestyle/style/mike-birbiglia-started-in-improv-everything-since-has-gone-according-to-plan/2017/10/12/ddb2fcda-aea5-11e7-be94-fabb0f1e9ffb_story.html|work=Washington Post|date=12 October 2017}}</ref> He subsequently attended [[Georgetown University]] in Washington, D.C., graduating in 2000.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://georgetownvoice.com/2010/10/07/considerate-comedy-with-mike-birbiglia|work=Georgetown Voice|title=Considerate comedy from Mike Birbiglia|first=Heather|last=Regen|date=October 7, 2010|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101031004156/http://georgetownvoice.com/2010/10/07/considerate-comedy-with-mike-birbiglia/|archivedate=October 31, 2010|df=mdy-all}}</ref> During college he performed as a member of the Georgetown Players Improv Troupe, worked as a server in a comedy club, and began performing at DC Improv ([[The Improv]] ) in Washington, D.C.<ref name="All Things 2014">{{cite web|title=To Mike Birbiglia's Parents: It's OK If Your Son Sticks To Comedy|url=https://www.npr.org/2014/03/23/292990239/to-mike-birbiglias-parents-its-ok-if-your-son-sticks-to-comedy|website=[[All Things Considered]]|publisher=NPR|language=en|date=March 23, 2014}}</ref><ref name="WAPO-Bacic"/>
==Early career (2000–2008) == Birbiglia moved to New York in 2000,<ref name="Why failure">{{cite news|last1=Phillips|first1=Michael|title=Why failure is 'essential' to Mike Birbiglia|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/entertainment/movies/ct-mike-birbiglia-dont-think-twice-mov-0729-20160728-column.html|work=Chicago Tribune|date=July 28, 2016}}</ref> and appeared on the ''[[Late Show with David Letterman]]'' in 2002.<ref name="All Things 2014"/> He told his first story on stage at the [[U.S. Comedy Arts Festival]] in Aspen, in 2003, and eventually became a semi-regular contributor to ''[[The Moth]]'' storytelling series.<ref name="Fresh Air 2010"/> He released his first album, ''Dog Years'', in 2004,<ref name="Broadway.com">{{cite web|last1=Galtney|first1=Smith|title=Mike Birbiglia|url=https://www.broadway.com/buzz/6666/mike-birbiglia/|website=Broadway.com|accessdate=19 December 2017|language=en|date=December 18, 2008}}</ref> followed by ''My Secret Public Album, Volume 1a'' (2005) a compilation of his appearances on ''[[The Bob and Tom Show]]''. His next two albums, ''Two Drink Mike'' (2006), and ''My Secret Public Journal Live'' (2007) were released on [[Comedy Central Records]]. ''My Secret Public Journal Live'' was named one of the best comedy albums of the decade by [[The A.V. Club]]<ref>{{cite web|author=Staff|date=November 16, 2009|url=http://www.avclub.com/articles/the-best-comedy-albums-of-the-decade,35403|title=The best comedy albums of the decade | Music | Best of|publisher=The A.V. Club|accessdate=September 13, 2010|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100912062812/http://www.avclub.com/articles/the-best-comedy-albums-of-the-decade%2C35403/|archivedate=September 12, 2010|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
In 2007 Birbiglia starred in the independent feature film ''Stanley Cuba'', which debuted at the [[Santa Barbara International Film Festival]] and played in the [[Brooklyn Film Festival|Brooklyn]] and [[Milan Film Festival|Milan]] film festivals.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Weight|first1=Rachel|title=Introducing Stanley Cuba|url=https://www.independent.com/news/2007/jan/23/introducing-stanley-cuba/|work=Santa Barbara Independent|date=January 23, 2007|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=STANLEY CUBA by Per Anderson - Narrative Feature Film @ Brooklyn Film Festival|url=http://www.brooklynfilmfestival.org/films/detail.asp?fid=775|website=www.brooklynfilmfestival.org|accessdate=22 December 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Stanley Cuba {{!}} 8° Film Festival Internazionale di Milano|url=http://www.miff.it/scheda.php?lang=1?ph=archivio&id=231|website=www.miff.it|accessdate=22 December 2017}}</ref> In 2008 [[CBS]] picked up a sitcom pilot loosely based on Birbiglia's life and featuring himself, [[Bob Odenkirk]] and [[Frances Conroy]] that ultimately never aired.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Adalian|first1=Josef|title=CBS greenlights ‘Mike Birbiglia’ pilot|url=https://variety.com/2008/scene/markets-festivals/cbs-greenlights-mike-birbiglia-pilot-1117982496/|work=Variety|date=15 March 2008}}</ref><ref name="Why failure"/> He later called the failure of his pilot "the luckiest thing that ever happened to me."<ref name="Vulture-2016">{{cite news|last1=Fox|first1=Jesse David|title=Mike Birbiglia’s Quest to Create Comedy of Communion|url=http://www.vulture.com/2016/07/mike-birbiglia-dont-think-twice.html|work=Vulture|date=19 July 2016|language=en}}</ref>
==''Sleepwalk'' and beyond (2008–present)==
In 2008, Birbiglia opened ''Sleepwalk with Me'', a one-man show that straddled standup comedy and theater, [[off-Broadway]] at the [[Bleecker Street Theater]].<ref>{{Cite news|last=Scheck|first=Frank|url=http://www.nypost.com/seven/11172008/entertainment/theater/for_cryin__laughin_out_loud_139094.htm|title=For Cryin' & Laughin' Out Loud|newspaper=[[New York Post]]|date=November 17, 2008|accessdate=September 13, 2010|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090227155836/http://www.nypost.com/seven/11172008/entertainment/theater/for_cryin__laughin_out_loud_139094.htm|archivedate=February 27, 2009|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|url=http://www.variety.com/review/VE1117938986.html?categoryid=33&cs=1&query=sleepwalk+with+me|title=Theater Review: Sleepwalk With Me – Theater and Musical Production Reviews|magazine=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|accessdate=September 13, 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090228070324/http://www.variety.com/review/VE1117938986.html?categoryid=33&cs=1&query=sleepwalk+with+me|archivedate=February 28, 2009|df=mdy-all}}</ref> The show was presented by [[Nathan Lane]], and the ''[[New York Times]]'' called it "simply perfect".<ref>{{Cite news |last=Genzlinger |first=Neil |url=http://theater2.nytimes.com/2008/11/14/theater/reviews/14Slee.html |title=Theater Review – 'Sleepwalk With Me' – Mike Birbiglia in a One-Man Show at the Bleecker Street Theater |newspaper=[[New York Times]] |date=November 14, 2008 |accessdate=September 13, 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090609091503/http://theater2.nytimes.com/2008/11/14/theater/reviews/14Slee.html |archivedate=June 9, 2009 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> ''[[Time Out New York]]'' named it their "Show of the Year" in 2009.<ref>{{cite news|last=Borden|first=Jane|title=Best (and Worst) of 2009|url=http://www.timeout.com/newyork/comedy/best-and-worst-of-2009|accessdate=April 2, 2012|newspaper=Time Out New York|date=December 18, 2009|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140821164158/http://www.timeout.com/newyork/comedy/best-and-worst-of-2009|archivedate=August 21, 2014|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
Birbiglia adapted his material into the 2010 book ''Sleepwalk with Me, and Other Painfully True Stories'' and the 2011 album ''Sleepwalk With Me Live''. The book debuted at #29 on the hardcover nonfiction ''[[New York Times Bestseller List]]''<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.broadwayworld.com/article/SLEEPWALK_WITH_ME_And_Other_Painfully_True_Stories_Hits_NY_Times_Bestseller_List_20101021|title=''Sleepwalk With Me and Other Painfully True Stories'' Hits NY Times Bestseller List|newspaper=BroadwayWorld.com|date=October 21, 2010|accessdate=October 24, 2010|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121006183602/http://broadwayworld.com/article/SLEEPWALK_WITH_ME_And_Other_Painfully_True_Stories_Hits_NY_Times_Bestseller_List_20101021|archivedate=October 6, 2012|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/10/31/books/bestseller/besthardnonfiction.html|title=Best Sellers: Hardcover Nonfiction|newspaper=New York Times|date=October 22, 2010|accessdate=October 23, 2010|first=Jennifer|last=Schuessler}}</ref> and number four on the hardcover nonfiction section of the ''[[Washington Post]]'' Political Bookworm Best Sellers.<ref name=WaPoB>{{cite news|url=http://voices.washingtonpost.com/political-bookworm/2010/10/post_7.html|newspaper=Washington Post|title=Political Bookworm: Book World: Best Sellers|author=Levingston, Steven|date=October 24, 2010|accessdate=October 29, 2010}}</ref> The book was also a finalist for the 2011 [[Thurber Prize for American Humor]].<ref>{{cite news|last=McCarthy|first=Sean|title=2011 Thurber Prize Finalists: Mike Birbiglia, David Rakoff, and Rick Reilly|url=http://thecomicscomic.com/2011/08/22/2011-thurber-prize-finalists-mike-birbiglia-david-rakoff-and-rick-reilly|accessdate=April 2, 2012|newspaper=The Comic's Comic|date=August 22, 2011|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140822090140/http://thecomicscomic.com/2011/08/22/2011-thurber-prize-finalists-mike-birbiglia-david-rakoff-and-rick-reilly/|archivedate=August 22, 2014|df=mdy-all}}</ref> ''Sleepwalk With Me Live'' debuted at #1 on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' Comedy Charts.<ref>{{cite web|title=Comedy Albums, Week of May 7, 2011|url=http://www.billboard.com/charts/comedy-albums#/charts/comedy-albums?chartDate=2011-05-09|work=Billboard|accessdate=April 2, 2012|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160822192809/http://www.billboard.com/charts/comedy-albums#/charts/comedy-albums?chartDate=2011-05-09|archivedate=August 22, 2016|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
[[File:Comedian Mike Birbiglia performs during the comedy show in celebration of the 75th anniversary of the USO and the 5th anniversary of Joining Forces (26777224311).jpg|thumb|Birbiglia performing in 2016]]
Birbiglia made his directorial debut with ''[[Sleepwalk with Me]]'', based on his one-man show and which he wrote, directed, and starred in. The film premiered at the 2012 [[Sundance Film Festival]] and won the NEXT Audience Award.<ref>{{cite web|last=Rich|first=Katey|title=Top Sundance Prizes Go To Beasts Of the Southern Wild, The House I Live In, And More|url=http://www.cinemablend.com/new/Top-Sundance-Prizes-Go-Beasts-Southern-Wild-House-I-Live-More-29107.html|publisher=Cinemablend.com|accessdate=February 16, 2012|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120202135204/http://www.cinemablend.com/new/Top-Sundance-Prizes-Go-Beasts-Southern-Wild-House-I-Live-More-29107.html|archivedate=February 2, 2012|df=mdy-all}}</ref> It was selected in the "Festival Favorites" category at the [[South by Southwest]] film festival in Austin, Texas <ref>{{cite news|last=Odam|first=Matthew|title=SXSW adds Seth MacFarlane, ‘Blue Like Jazz’, ‘Sleepwalk With Me’ and more|url=http://www.austin360.com/blogs/content/shared-gen/blogs/austin/austinmovies/entries/2012/02/15/sxsw_adds_seth_macfarlane_blue.html?cxntfid=blogs_austin_movie_blog|accessdate=February 16, 2012|newspaper=Austin360.com|date=February 15, 2012|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120222000533/http://www.austin360.com/blogs/content/shared-gen/blogs/austin/austinmovies/entries/2012/02/15/sxsw_adds_seth_macfarlane_blue.html?cxntfid=blogs_austin_movie_blog|archivedate=February 22, 2012|df=mdy-all}}</ref> and also appeared in the [[Nantucket Film Festival]] where it won the award for best writer/director.<ref>{{cite web|title=Mike Birbiglia's ''Sleepwalk With Me'' Wins Nantucket Film Festival Award|url=http://www.theatermania.com/all-cities/news/06-2012/mike-birbiglias-sleepwalk-with-me-wins-nantucket-f_58754.html|publisher=theater mania|accessdate=June 25, 2012|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120714032327/http://www.theatermania.com/all-cities/news/06-2012/mike-birbiglias-sleepwalk-with-me-wins-nantucket-f_58754.html|archivedate=July 14, 2012|df=mdy-all}}</ref> The film was produced by Jacob Jaffke and ''[[This American Life]]'''s [[Ira Glass]] and stars Birbiglia, [[Lauren Ambrose]], [[Carol Kane]], [[James Rebhorn]], and [[Cristin Milioti]] and has cameos by Glass, [[Kristen Schaal]], [[Wyatt Cenac]], [[David Wain]], [[Jessi Klein]], [[John Lutz]] and [[Marc Maron]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Sleepwalk With Me (2011)|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2077851/|publisher=Internet Movie Database|accessdate=April 2, 2012|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120407033805/http://www.imdb.com/title/tt2077851/|archivedate=April 7, 2012|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
In addition to starring in ''Sleepwalk with Me'', Birbiglia has appeared in films such as ''[[Trainwreck (film)|Trainwreck]]'', ''[[Going the Distance (2010 film)|Going the Distance]]'', ''[[Cedar Rapids (film)|Cedar Rapids]]'', ''[[Your Sister's Sister]]'' and ''[[The Fault in Our Stars (film)|The Fault in Our Stars]]''. He has also guest-starred in episodes of ''[[Girls (TV series)|Girls]]'', ''[[Inside Amy Schumer]]'', and ''[[Broad City]]''.<ref>{{cite web|title=Mike Birbiglia|url=https://www.imdb.com/name/nm1898126/|publisher=Internet Movie Database|accessdate=April 2, 2012|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120614062956/http://www.imdb.com/name/nm1898126/|archivedate=June 14, 2012|df=mdy-all}}</ref> He played the role of Danny Pearson on the Netflix series ''[[Orange Is the New Black]]'' in its third and fourth season, with which he shared the 2016 [[Screen Actors Guild Award for Outstanding Performance by an Ensemble in a Comedy Series]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Outstanding Film and Television Performances Honored at the 22nd Annual Screen Actors Guild Awards|url=https://www.sagawards.org/media-pr/press-releases/outstanding-film-and-television-performances-honored-22nd-annual-screen|website=www.sagawards.org|language=en|date=January 30, 2016}}</ref>
[[File:Mike Birbiglia and Aidy Bryant.webm|thumb|left| Birbiglia and [[Aidy Bryant]] at the 2015 [[Del Close Marathon]] discuss comedy, the [[Upright Citizens Brigade]], and comedian [[Amy Poehler]]]] In 2011, Birbiglia mounted his second one-man show, ''My Girlfriend's Boyfriend'', which ran for four months off-Broadway and won the [[Lucille Lortel Award]] for Outstanding Solo Show.<ref>{{cite web|last=Jones |first=Kenneth |title=Bloody Bloody Andrew Jackson, Chad Deity, Angels, Christian Borle, Laurie Metcalf Are Lortel Winners |url=http://www.playbill.com/news/article/150396-Bloody-Bloody-Andrew-Jackson-Chad-Deity-Angels-Christian-Borle-Laurie-Metcalf-Are-Lortel-Winners |work=Playbill |accessdate=April 2, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120327191215/http://www.playbill.com/news/article/150396-Bloody-Bloody-Andrew-Jackson-Chad-Deity-Angels-Christian-Borle-Laurie-Metcalf-Are-Lortel-Winners |archivedate=March 27, 2012 |df= }}</ref> He toured ''My Girlfriend's Boyfriend'' around the world with tour dates in the United States, Australia, Canada and the United Kingdom. On June 2, 2013, Birbiglia performed it for the last time at [[Carnegie Hall]].<ref name=playbill>{{cite web|last=Gans |first=Andrew |title=Mike Birbiglia's My Girlfriend's Boyfriend Plays Carnegie Hall June 2 |url=http://www.playbill.com/news/article/178559-Mike-Birbiglias-My-Girlfriends-Boyfriend-Plays-Carnegie-Hall-June-2 |work=Playbill |accessdate=July 27, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130605204046/http://www.playbill.com/news/article/178559-Mike-Birbiglias-My-Girlfriends-Boyfriend-Plays-Carnegie-Hall-June-2 |archivedate=June 5, 2013 |df= }}</ref><ref name=splitsider>{{cite web|last=Fox|first=Jesse David|title=Birbiglia Is Already Working on His Second Feature, 'My Girlfriend's Boyfriend'|url=http://splitsider.com/2012/08/birbiglia-is-already-working-on-his-second-feature-my-girlfriends-boyfriend/|publisher=Splitsider|accessdate=July 27, 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130420194313/http://splitsider.com/2012/08/birbiglia-is-already-working-on-his-second-feature-my-girlfriends-boyfriend/|archivedate=April 20, 2013|df=mdy-all}}</ref> ''My Girlfriend's Boyfriend'' was featured as the number one stand-up special of 2013 by [[Vulture.com|Vulture]],<ref>{{cite web|last=Fox|first=Jesse|title=The Top Ten Stand-up Specials of 2013|url=http://www.vulture.com/2013/12/top-ten-stand-up-specials-of-2013.html|publisher=Vulture|accessdate=February 6, 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140217053146/http://www.vulture.com/2013/12/top-ten-stand-up-specials-of-2013.html|archivedate=February 17, 2014|df=mdy-all}}</ref> [[Paste (magazine)|''Paste'']],<ref>{{cite web|author=Staff|work=Paste|title=The 10 Best Stand-Up Specials of 2013|url=http://www.pastemagazine.com/blogs/lists/2013/12/the-10-best-stand-up-specials-of-2013.html|accessdate=February 6, 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140131221227/http://www.pastemagazine.com/blogs/lists/2013/12/the-10-best-stand-up-specials-of-2013.html|archivedate=January 31, 2014|df=mdy-all}}</ref> The Laugh Button<ref>{{cite web|publisher=The Laugh Button|title=The Laugh Button's Best Comedy Albums of 2013|url=http://thelaughbutton.com/features/laugh-buttons-comedy-albums-2013|accessdate=February 6, 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140126201909/http://thelaughbutton.com/features/laugh-buttons-comedy-albums-2013/|archivedate=January 26, 2014|df=mdy-all}}</ref> and Laughspin.<ref>{{cite web|last=Gadino |first=Dylan |title=The 10 Best Comedy Albums of 2013 |url=http://www.laughspin.com/2013/12/18/laughspin-presents-the-10-best-comedy-albums-of-2013/ |publisher=Laughspin |accessdate=February 6, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140126095015/http://www.laughspin.com/2013/12/18/laughspin-presents-the-10-best-comedy-albums-of-2013/ |archivedate=January 26, 2014 |df= }}</ref> It was also named one of ''[[Time Out (magazine)|Time Out New York]]'''s Best Comedy Specials of 2013.<ref>{{cite web|last=Seabaugh|first=Julie|title=Best Comedy Specials of 2013|url=http://www.timeout.com/newyork/comedy/best-comedy-specials-of-2013|work=Time Out|location=New York|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140423230921/http://www.timeout.com/newyork/comedy/best-comedy-specials-of-2013|archivedate=April 23, 2014|df=mdy-all}}</ref> ''[[Flavorwire]]'' listed the special as one of the top 20 funniest stand-up specials of all time.<ref>{{cite web|last=Bailey|first=Jason|title=The 50 Funniest Stand-Up Specials of All Time|url=http://flavorwire.com/425677/the-50-funniest-stand-up-specials-of-all-time|work=Flavorwire|accessdate=February 6, 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140207115040/http://flavorwire.com/425677/the-50-funniest-stand-up-specials-of-all-time/|archivedate=February 7, 2014|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
For his second film, Birbiglia's drew upon his early experience with improv in ''[[Don't Think Twice]]'' (2016), which centers on a fictional Manhattan improv troupe.<ref name="WAPO-Bacic"/><ref>{{cite news|last1=Coyle|first1=Jake|title=Birbiglia gives improv its first close-up on the big screen|url=https://www.apnews.com/b2c4516cf5aa4cd7a7b5b9bf90cb830d/Birbiglia-gives-improv-its-first-close-up-on-the-big-screen|work=AP News|date=July 20, 2016}}</ref> Birbligia also stars among an ensemble cast including [[Keegan-Michael Key]], [[Gillian Jacobs]], [[Kate Micucci]], [[Tami Sagher]], and [[Chris Gethard]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Holden|first1=Stephen|title=Review: ‘Don’t Think Twice’: Mike Birbiglia’s Smart Comedy|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/07/22/movies/dont-think-twice-mike-birbliglia-improv-comedy-review.html|work=The New York Times|date=21 July 2016}}</ref> The film was nominated for several awards, including the [[22nd Critics' Choice Awards|Critics' Choice Award for Best Comedy]]<ref>{{cite web|last1=Davis|first1=Clayton|title=Denver Film Critics Society Nominations: Doubling Down on the Aaron Taylor-Johnson Surge|url=http://www.awardscircuit.com/2017/01/10/denver-film-critics-society-nominations-doubling-aaron-taylor-johnson-surge/|website=AwardsCircuit.com|date=10 January 2017}}</ref> and [[St. Louis Film Critics Association]] award for Best Comedy.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Wilson|first1=Calvin|title=St. Louis Film Critics Association announces nominations for awards|url=http://www.stltoday.com/entertainment/movies/st-louis-film-critics-association-announces-nominations-for-awards/article_a5ca6656-6f47-58d1-b570-35cd6bf8e4a8.html|work=stltoday.com|date=December 12, 2016|language=en}}</ref>
Birbiglia's ''Thank God for Jokes'' comedy special was released on Netflix on February 28, 2017.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://splitsider.com/2017/02/mike-birbiglias-thank-god-for-jokes-premieres-on-netflix-next-week/ |title=Mike Birbiglia’s ‘Thank God For Jokes’ Premieres on Netflix Next Week |publisher=Splitsider |accessdate=2017-03-03 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170303123822/http://splitsider.com/2017/02/mike-birbiglias-thank-god-for-jokes-premieres-on-netflix-next-week/ |archivedate=March 3, 2017 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
==On ''This American Life''== Birbiglia is a regular contributor to the [[Public Radio International]]-distributed program ''[[This American Life]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thisamericanlife.org/contributors/mike-birbiglia|title=Contributors List: Mike Birbiglia|work=[[This American Life]]|publisher=[[Chicago Public Radio]]|accessdate=September 27, 2010}}</ref><ref name="Orr 2016">{{cite news|last1=Orr|first1=Christopher|title=Mike Birbiglia's Quiet Ambition|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/entertainment/archive/2016/07/mike-birbiglia-dont-think-twice/492524/|work=The Atlantic|date=July 22, 2016}}</ref>
==Personal life== Birbiglia has [[rapid eye movement sleep behavior disorder]], which once caused him to run out of a second-story window of a motel he was staying in [[Walla Walla, Washington]], while on tour. As a result of the accident, Birbiglia received 33 stitches in his leg.<ref name="Fresh Air 2010">{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=130644070|title=Spending The Night With Sleepwalker Mike Birbiglia|date=October 18, 2010|work=[[Fresh Air]]|publisher=[[WHYY-FM|WHYY]]|accessdate=October 27, 2010|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101031165644/http://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=130644070|archivedate=October 31, 2010|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref name="acp">{{cite web|work=[[The Adam Carolla Show (podcast)|The Adam Carolla Show]] |format=[[podcast]] |url=http://www.adamcarolla.com/ACPBlog/2010/10/14/mike-birbiglia |date=October 14, 2010 |title=Mike Birbiglia |accessdate=October 27, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101018041814/http://www.adamcarolla.com/ACPBlog/2010/10/14/mike-birbiglia/ |archivedate=October 18, 2010 |df= }}</ref><ref name=WE>{{cite news| url=http://washingtonexaminer.com/comedian-mike-birbiglia-returns-to-the-scene-of-the-crime/article/22126| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131123004921/http://washingtonexaminer.com/comedian-mike-birbiglia-returns-to-the-scene-of-the-crime/article/22126| archivedate=November 23, 2013| title=Comedian Mike Birbiglia returns to the scene of the crime| last=Klimek|first=Chris| date=October 9, 2009| work=[[Washington Examiner]]| deadurl=no| accessdate=November 23, 2013}}</ref>
Birbiglia is married to Jen Stein. They have one daughter, Oona.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://celebritybabies.people.com/2015/06/27/mike-birbiglia-president-obama-parenting-advice/|title=Mike Birbiglia on President Obama’s Parenting Advice|work=People|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150705101625/http://celebritybabies.people.com/2015/06/27/mike-birbiglia-president-obama-parenting-advice/|archivedate=July 5, 2015|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
